These are examples that should be warnings to us, like what we find in the book of 1 Corinthians when God says to the believers in Corinth, He says, listen, Paul is speaking to them, and he says, listen, with many of them God was not well pleased. In other words, take heed. Don't follow their example. Don't follow their behavior. And I hope this evening that we can learn from some negative behavior in Genesis 27. And we can guard against in our lives relying on our own understanding and thinking that we have to scheme. I said this often throughout the last couple of chapters of the book of Genesis. Living by faith does not require scheming. It just doesn't. We do not have to scheme in this life. We can trust God. You say, but I don't see a way. Neither did they. You don't want to go down that path. Amen? As soon as you allow that thought, I don't see a way, and I have to start relying on my own understanding, you start going down a path that leads to poor decision making apart from God this evening. My heart is saddened by Genesis 27, I'm just being transparent with you this evening. As I meditated upon this passage this week, and I read it again this afternoon, and I'm like, this is heartbreaking to see so much carnality and deception in one chapter of God's precious book by people that had previously inquired of the Lord. When Isaac and Rebekah had no children, what did they do? In Genesis 25, what did they do? The two of them prayed, said, God, we have no children. God blessed. When Rebekah was, there's a struggle within the womb, she inquired of the Lord, and God answered. And how easy it is for us to rely on our own understanding, and to think that we need to figure things out. I don't know how God could have or would have worked in Genesis 27. It's hypothetical. Because the decisions were made that resulted in the consequences that are recorded. But wouldn't it be interesting in your mind to just think about some of the other passages of Scripture that we read and we see God moving and working in phenomenal ways and bringing to pass those things that you'd say, we never could figure out how this was going to happen. But God. You ever read those statements in the Word of God? But God. You say, man, this is exciting. Because God did what only God could do. The Bible tells us in Psalm 78, and I'll end with this. Psalm 78 is a long psalm. And it deals primarily, it records a lot of the history of Israel and it goes through a number of events. Somewhere around verse number 41, the Bible says this, that they, the children of Israel, limited the Holy One of Israel. The unlimited God, the Almighty God. What limited Him? Their unbelief. Their sin. Their scheming. This evening, I don't want to limit God. I don't want to see what my plan can bring to pass. Didn't work out well for them in Genesis 27. For Rebekah and Jacob, their plan didn't work out well. He received the blessing. I want to see God's plan. Amen? See what God can do. Because we serve the Almighty Creator of the universe. And He is able, as I said this morning in Sunday school, to do exceeding abundantly above all that we ask or think. Joseph at once said, daddy, you forgot to emphasize that word all in Sunday school. You talked about all the other words. But all. So Joseph, there you go. All that we ask or think, amen? He is. We serve a great God. Let's trust Him and let Him have His way. Let's pray. Father, we love You. Thank You for loving us. I know that it's so easy, perhaps easier for some than others, but it's so easy as humans to want to take things, matters, into our own hands. God, I pray that tonight You'd help us to learn from this passage of Scripture to rely fully upon Thee, that we might see You do the impossible from our human perspective, that we might see You do what we might not even be able to imagine. Help us to live by faith without scheming, refusing to even start down that path. Help us to simply trust You. Well, thank You, God, for what You'll do in our hearts and lives as You teach us from Your Word. Would You move and work as only You can, for it's in Christ's name we pray.
